Award.AwardTitle: Fostering Active Learning in Statistics: Research on Students and Graduate Teaching Assistants

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will address the established and growing national need (i) for United States citizenry as a whole to develop a better understanding of uses and applications of statistics in order to make informed decisions and (ii) to improve quality and increase quantity of college graduates to enter the workforce in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) areas with the ability to apply statistics to advance knowledge and information to help keep the Nation equipped with a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. Recently, much has been learned about the teaching and learning of undergraduate statistics, and one of the recommendations in statistics education is to foster active learning in the classroom. In connection with this, the investigators will: (a) produce materials to foster active and lasting learning for undergraduate students in introductory statistics courses; (b) train statistics graduate teaching assistants (GTAs) in the content and pedagogical issues needed to implement these materials effectively; and (c) conduct research to understand and generate improvements regarding the effectiveness of the developed materials and the graduate student training.

The goals of this project are to produce and disseminate a research-based student manual and instructor's guide along with the associated materials necessary to train GTAs to facilitate active learning experiences. Another outcome of the project will be an addition to the body of research on the professional development needs of GTAs to implement successfully active-learning experiences in undergraduate classrooms. In 2010, over 500,000 students were enrolled in introductory statistics at the undergraduate level in the U.S., an increase of over 65% over the previous decade, and many of these courses are taught by GTAs. So research related to GTA training is imperative. The following research questions will be investigated. (1) To what extent do the active learning labs result in higher levels cognitive learning outcomes, attitudes toward statistics, and successful completion of introductory statistics course? (2) What is the content and pedagogical knowledge needed by GTAs in statistics to facilitate active learning labs and how does their knowledge change as a result of facilitating active learning? The questions will be addressed using mixed methods, repeated measures, and hierarchal models. Materials generated from the project will be portable to other institutions, and the accompanying research will inform these institutions; whereas, information generated from the research on professional development not only will apply to institutions with GTAs, but will also be pertinent to any higher education institution where introductory undergraduate statistics is taught.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recently, much has been learned about the teaching and learning of undergraduate statistics with particular focus on fostering active learning in the classroom, one of the ASA endorsed recommendations for teaching undergraduate statistics and a general recommendation for improving learning in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). In connection with this, the investigators produced materials to (a) foster active learning for undergraduate students in introductory statistics courses and (b) train graduate teaching assistants (GTAs) in statistics in the content and pedagogy needed to implement the materials effectively and (c) conducted research to understand and generate improvements regarding the effectiveness of the developed materials and the GTA training. The intellectual merit of this project with respect to the advancement of scientific knowledge is two-fold: the research results have led to improvements in educator development in STEM, which in turn leads to improved undergraduate STEM learning. For broader impacts, this project meets the desired societal outcomes of 1) improving STEM education and educator development at the undergraduate level and 2) providing enhanced infrastructure for research in teaching and learning of undergraduates in STEM courses.

The project produced a Student Lab Manual with 12 student-centered activities for use in a typical Introductory Statistics course. In addition to the Student Lab Manual, the project produced an Instructor Manual and a Training Manual with accompanying videos of an instructor implementing the activities. The activities in the Student Lab Manual are designed to be completed by students in small groups and focus on the conceptual ideas of statistics. The activities include explicit statements of Student Learning Outcomes and Important Points for each Lab and end with a Sample Assessment of the content covered by the Lab. The Instructor Manual is written for GTAs assigned to facilitate the Student Labs. Instructions for each Lab include explicit suggestions for the timing of each Lab and statement of parts of the Lab with which students might struggle, including suggestions for generating discussions and responding to questions. The Training Manual is designed for use by the faculty member who coordinates the course associated with the Labs and for each Lab includes not only suggestions for discussions during the training, some aligned to the Lab videos, but also explicit statements of expectations of the GTAs and content that GTAs may find difficult to explain.

During the project period, the research team worked closely with the faculty member who trained the GTAs using the materials and observed at least 5 hours of implementation of each Lab in each of 4 semesters as well as all of the training sessions in those sessions. Through these observations, we learned that GTAs struggle with instructional pacing and closure of activity-based sessions and revised the materials to address these issues. The results of the Lab observations indicated that by the end of the two-year project, the GTAs who facilitated the labs were doing less presenting and more moving around the class and guiding the students in group work. In addition, students were listening less and doing more work in groups and individually. GTA survey results indicated that the GTAs felt more comfortable with student-centered and activity-based instruction at the end of their time in the program. GTAs specifically expressed better affect and higher beliefs towards using simulation and computer-based activities to express complex statistical content and using group-work as part of instruction. In terms of statistical content, our TAs felt uncomfortable, at the beginning of their instructional career, to teach experimental design and struggled with statistical inference. When exiting the project, TAs reported an improvement in content understanding on these topics.

The project results have been disseminated through talks at individual institutions (3), posters, presentations, and workshops at National meetings (7), one talk at an International meeting, and two peer-reviewed conference proceedings. Additional institutions are being solicited to pilot the materials created by the project to study the training model under different conditions. The PI of the project is now working with the University Center for Teaching and Learning, using the findings of the project to improve the training of GTAs at UGA for instruction. For example, she worked with a group of Future Faculty participants to prepare a session for the University New TA Orientation on how to be a lab GTA and with a group of instructors of the course on teaching required of all graduate student TA at UGA: helping them craft a syllabus and consider topics and activities that would help GTAs provide higher quality instruction and more opportunities for active learning for the undergraduate students in their classes.
